abstract:
<jats:p>We theoretically analyze the problem of testing for 
            <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐hacking based on distributions of 
            <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐values across multiple studies. We provide general results for when such distributions have testable restrictions (are non‐increasing) under the null of no 
            <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐hacking. We find novel additional testable restrictions for 
            <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐values based on 
            <jats:italic>t</jats:italic>‐tests. Specifically, the shape of the power functions results in both complete monotonicity as well as bounds on the distribution of 
            <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐values. These testable restrictions result in more powerful tests for the null hypothesis of no 
            <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐hacking. When there is also publication bias, our tests are joint tests for 
            <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐hacking and publication bias. A reanalysis of two prominent data sets shows the usefulness of our new tests.
          </jats:p>
title: Detecting p‐Hacking
